Title: Dragonfruit
Author: Makiia Lucier
My Review:
Read this book in a day while on the bus to/from DC for a Palestine March to conserve phone battery. Tbh I was pretty sleep deprived so my experience is colored by that.

My main gripe is that I would have liked this book much better as a three+ part series. It crammed such an ambitious story into a relatively small novel. So many characters, overlapping backstories, magical systems , etc. I left the book feeling like most of the ideas were half baked. Because of this I didn’t feel much emotion while reading it. My feelings of sadness or excitement were muted, a fraction of what they would have been if the story and characters were fleshed out

Title: Good Son
Author: Kyle Liang
My Review:
The first poetry book I've read!! Amazing set of poems that span many different facets of the author's life. Each poem was its own journey and I was glad to travel through them all.

This is a book I will definitely return to, and poems that I will continue thinking about long after I read the last page.

Title: The Midnight Library
Author: Matt Haig
My Review:
This book deals with themes of regret, yearning, and the feeling that your life is over and you've squandered all potential. I struggle a lot with spending enormous amounts of mental energy thinking through every life I could be living. Even if I'm satisfied with my current life, I mourn the simple fact that I will never be able to experience every possible version of myself.

This book put into words a lot of these feelings, and more than just verbalizing them, offers a new perspective through which I felt genuine hope and excitement about the fact that I have so many possible lives, rather than only dread.

The premise isn't the most original, and the platitudes offered are not entirely groundbreaking, but I loved this story and openly wept as the main character slowly found their way throughout the story.

I also started reading this book while I was in Svalbard which was cool.

Title: Another Day in the Death of America: A Chronicle of Ten Short Lives
Author: Gary Younge
My Review: One of the best books I've read so far this year. The premise for the book hooked me immediately, and the author delivers well on the premise. Each story is so uniquely tragic, and the author connects them together in ways that show precisely why they are not unique. It shows exactly why our current system is completely unacceptable and that we can and must do better.

Title: Everything I Know About Love
Author: Dolly Alderton
My Review:
This book was pretty good, I think I just feel 3/5 about it because I feel like I've seen/read this type of stuff a million times over the past few years. A collection of essays from a millennial freelance blog writer in various witty formats, with stories of a friends sisters funeral right next to a hungover breakfast recipe. Funny anecdotes from wild nights out, shitty boyfriends, going to therapy, and platonic friendships.

The book was well-written, and I appreciated the focus on the love you find in platonic friendships. There were times that I laughed and cried, and times where I was driven to introspect about my own relationships between partners and friends. However, I feel like this book just joined the ever growing hum of banal self-help advice offered to me by millennials through Tumblr, Youtube, or printed media since I was a teenager. I think had I read this in high school, I would've taken the authors advice as gospel, as she has an enviable air of self-assuredness to her tone of writing. However, at this point in life I can accept that her life experiences are so wildly different from my own. And while I can appreciate the stories she shared and use it to drive my own inner feelings about love and friendship, I shouldn't take any of the advice or lessons too seriously.

Overall - good book, just felt very unoriginal and redundant to many, many pieces of media I've seen/read in the past. This is by no fault of the author, I think Alderton did a great job of telling her stories and reflecting on how they affected her. However, I think I'm just nearing my limit of how many times I can hear a millennial write about how excessive partying in college was not fulfilling and and how therapy helped them feel better etc. However I do think their is value in reflecting in these mundane, unoriginal experiences and romanticizing them to find love in all the places it exists.

Title: The Vegetarian
Author: Han Kang
My Review:
average vegan origin story.

Listened to this book while I was walking around Svalbard and it really resonated with me. This is one of those books about someone who is 'crazy' but written in such a way that each step further into insanity is clear and logical, and you're left wondering if you're not the crazy one for going along with society like everyone else.

Like many other readers I'm vegan - and this part of the book resonated a lot. The revulsion that comes with the deep understanding of what it means to eat meat - and the question of how any member of any society can be seen as normal when participating in such an act. I want to be like Yeong-hye and scream at the top of my lungs anytime anyone dares to bring meat anywhere near me, but alas.

The other main theme in this book that stuck out to me was patriarchy. Yeong-hye's husband is a total bitch, a complete disgrace of a human being, but also a figure so common in patriarchal societies that he's sickeningly mundane. The father is not far off, but his patriarchal violence is physical as well as emotional. The brother-in-law is at least somewhat intellectually honest with himself, and questions his desires, although he too becomes controlled by them and causes irreparable harm to everyone in his life.

My only complaint with this book was the ending, but I'm just a hopeful ending kinda guy.

Title: Lonely Castle in the Mirror
Author: Mizuki Tsujimura
My Review:
I was talking to the friend that recommended this book to me and I wanted to have some sort of grand insights or nuanced takes about Lonely Castle in the Mirror. But honestly I couldn't come up with beyond just repeating over and over again how much I loved this book and everything about it.

All the characters are written beautifully, with such care from the author. Each member in the found family inside the castle has such depth and is fleshed out in such a way that it makes the ending a well-deserved payoff. It left me with the same feeling I have after a perfectly portioned meal - neither hungry or bloated, but entirely satisfied.

I was taken back to a time not so long ago where I was a boy wishing to escape inside a fantasy world, and I wish I had this book to give a voice to all of the surprisingly complex feelings and experiences a child can have.

5/5 Please read this book and talk to me about it!!

Title: How Buildings Learn: What Happens After They're Built
Author: Stewart Brand

Title: The Will to Change: Men, Masculinity, and Love
Author: bell hooks
My Review:
This review will not be enough to cover the entirety of my thoughts about this book.

This book came very highly recommended and there was a lot that I really liked - especially in the early chapters. There was a lot of frankness in the writing about masculinity and men in the feminist movement - and a lot of things I had felt before that I had never seen put into words. Something that stood out to me was that men do suffer under the patriarchy in terrible ways - but they are rewarded for it.

However, there was a lot about this book that rang completely false to my lived experience and that of the men in my life. I don't think that means that it makes the book wrong or unhelpful, but it was important for me to approach parts of this book with an open mind, but also accept that many things presented will not be relevant to me or those in my circles.

I do think this book is aimed more towards women than men, but I think that people of any gender can take away a host of things from this book. It helped me introspect on what I value in my life, and how I can hold myself and especially the men in my life to a higher standard. It also gave me a deeper appreciation for the women I have in my life, friends, family and mentors who have shown me love and see me as a complete person.

Title: The House on Mango Street
Author: Sandra Cisneros
My Review:
Let me start by saying that I listened to this as an audiobook at 2.5x on Spotify - which i believe is hardly the ideal format to experience this book and I concede this probably impacts my rating.

I could see the ideal setting for me reading this book is in an elementary or perhaps middle school classroom, reading a few passages at a time, and digesting the various motifs in the poem. Instead I’m in my mid twenties listening to the dramatically sped up version so I can optimize my literature consumption as I run to catch my subway, missing a few words here or there as my attention changes.

Some of the poems were interesting, but none sparked enough in me to give them a second go, or challenge any preconceived notions. I don’t doubt that this book probably has its place as classroom curriculum, or has touched many people - but unfortunately I was not one of them.

Title: The Anthropocene Reviewed
Author: John Green
My Review:
I've been watching Vlogbrothers for around 10 years at this point. I've followed the Green brothers and their various initiatives, projects, and ramblings for nearly half my life. However, I've never enjoyed John Green's novels much. That's not for lack of trying - I've read The Fault in Our Stars, Paper Towns, and Looking for Alaska. However, this book is different.

Many parts are not relatable to me. I would give other ratings and have different opinions and experiences about nearly everything mentioned in the book. It feels frustrating and wrong when you search for your favorite or least favorite restaurant on Yelp and don't see people agreeing with your opinion. However, with this book, the diverging opinions of the authors and me were not an issue. Beyond everything else, Green's writing conveys how much he cares about this Earth, this life, and everything about it. It's profoundly moving, and sometimes it feels like I'm reading scripture. Not because this book contains any holy divinations but because it views the world through a wondrous lens that I have often only heard when reading religious accounts of the Earth's creation.

If you're familiar with the voice of John Green through either his YouTube videos or his other novels - this is a book you can put down and pick up at any point. Each chapter is a mini essay (or Vlogbrothers video) that is self-contained and often has its own characters, arc, and moral. Usually, I'm not too fond of this format, but I enjoyed it this time. I was encouraged to read on not by cliffhangers and plot devices but by the chance to learn something new or hear a known topic discussed by someone whose opinion I have learned to respect.

I give The Anthropocene Reviewed five stars.

Title: Holding Pattern
Author: Jenny Xie
My Review:
I picked up this book bc my coworker wrote it :)

The premise of Midas Touch was compelling to me. The explorations of how physical contact with friends, family, lovers and strangers can affect you and how we all need physical contact in a society that discourages it at every turn. I enjoyed the nuance of the characters it really felt like the novel uncovered hidden dimensions of almost all the main characters involved.

However, the book lost me a bit in the second half. I became less interested in the mother-daughter dynamic as the novel wore on. I think this is because a lot of content and feelings were repeated, and live events were told twice—although with different perspectives each time. I wish the present-day Midas touch storyline was explored more, and it sometimes felt a bit off-pace to switch between mother-daughter dynamics both in the past and present and the Midas touch storyline.

Overall, I liked it! It made me reflect on and consider different ideas, which is what I want from a novel.

Title: Before the Coffee Gets Cold (Before the Coffee Gets Cold, #1)
Author: Toshikazu Kawaguchi
My Review:
This book was a fun, quick read. I liked the premise and how each chapter contained a separate story. However, I found pretty much all of the stories to be pretty conservative and patriarchal - which was disappointing.

1st story: The narrator is the most beautiful woman alive but doesn't notice because she's so focused on her career. However, she starts dating a shy, self-conscious nerd. Once he breaks up with her on the same day he's leaving for America - she is desperate to get him back. She travels back in time to beg him not to go. This story reeked of tired old romance tropes. It reduced the main character to a desperate girl patiently waiting 3 years for a mediocre man to return from America.

2nd story: A woman's husband gets dementia. She explains that he never got her gifts or even wrote a love letter to her throughout her marriage. She travels back in time, hoping he might write her something showing he loves her. And once he no longer remembers her, she still remains as his caretaker until he dies. Her expectation as a wife is to accept whatever scraps of affection her husband offers to show her and to stay his nurse and caretaker throughout it all.

3rd story: A woman leaves behind her family and their rigid expectations of her to become a bartender. When her sister dies, her parents don't even talk to her because they blame her for the death and resent her for choosing a different path in life than the one they had laid out. However, when she goes back in time to visit her now-dead sister, she decides she must be the proper daughter her parents want her to be to make amends. She moves back home, forsaking her own dream. Her expectation as a daughter and sister is to live out her life in service of a dead sister and parents who only acknowledge her when she is following their rules.

4th story: An ill woman decides to have a pregnancy despite knowing that it will kill her. This is framed as a highly selfless act to an unborn child instead of the unnecessary loss of life that it is. Mind you, this book is set in modern days, where there is absolutely no excuse for a mother to die for their unborn child. It is so much better to live for those who you love (including potential future children) than sacrifice yourself for an unborn child.

Each of these stories perpetuates gendered, conservative stereotypes about family and relationships. While each story has tender, wholesome moments that show genuine love and character growth, I found this book disappointing overall. It squandered so much potential for 4 stories that feel like they would have been mainstream narratives in the 1800s.

Title: Counterfeit
Author: Kirstin Chen
My Review: I liked this book! It was a quick read with a fun twist and multi-faceted characters. Maybe not the most profound or thought-provoking literature, but I enjoyed it the whole way through. The suspense, the reveals, and the slow build made the book one of my favorites so far this year.

Title: Race After Technology: Abolitionist Tools for the New Jim Code
Author: Ruha Benjamin

Title: Unmasking AI: My Mission to Protect What Is Human in a World of Machines
Author: Joy Buolamwini

Title: Stiff: The Curious Lives of Human Cadavers
Author: Mary Roach
My Review:
It was interesting to put the natural fear and revulsion of corpses to the side while reading this book to take a deep dive on cadavers as they're used now and throughout history. I learned a lot of fun facts and interesting anecdotes that kept. me engaged from start to finish. However, this book felt more like a collection of short stories than a cohesive novel. I think I would have enjoyed this book more a chapter at a time rather than reading it all in one go.

My biggest disappointment in this book is the utter lack of regard for animals and animal welfare. When vivisection or animal testing is mentioned, it's flippant, and animal rights and anti-vivisectionist movements are painted as extreme. I appreciated that despite the dry-humor tone of this book, the author still explores the topic of human cadavers with some amount of empathy and humanity. I wish she offered the same to animals.

Title: Yellowface
Author: R.F. Kuang
My Review: Read this novel for a book club. Reading this after Babel and Poppy Wars made the meta references really stand out. Wish I had friends IRL that I could discuss it with!

Title: Minor Feelings: An Asian American Reckoning
Author: Cathy Park Hong

Title: The Sexual Politics of Meat: A Feminist-Vegetarian Critical Theory
Author: Carol J. Adams

Title: I'm Glad My Mom Died
Author: Jennette McCurdy
My Review:
This book was absolutely heartbreaking to read. I see many of the reviews of this book, and McCurdy herself writes that the book is depressingly funny, but I struggled to find much humor. What I did find, however, was an honest account of someone struggling with fame, eating disorders, and living a life that did not belong to herself. McCurdy is blunt in her failings, her insecurities, and the trauma she experienced at the hands of her mother. I found myself grateful to be reading about another person who struggles with finding their identity even once they are an adult, especially someone like McCurdy, who could do it with so much to work through.

Reading this book the same week as crying in HMart left me reeling and my thoughts and emotions towards death and motherhood a jumbled mess. I could write a 10-page essay on the comparisons between the two, but I'll just hope someone makes a 1-hour video essay I can watch instead.

Also, I had no idea Jennette McCurdy grew up Mormon, lol.

Title: Crying in H Mart
Author: Michelle Zauner
My Review: Picked this book up after hearing about it from friends for the past 2 years. The authors description of grief was so intense it made me cry on more than one occasion. I think because I haven't lost a parent or anyone close to me before, I felt like the sadness in this book was more overwhelming than relatable, although I'm sure that will change with age and life experience. Immediately after finishing this book I called my mom lol.

Title: Tomorrow, and Tomorrow, and Tomorrow
Author: Gabrielle Zevin
My Review:
A coworker recommended this to me after finishing Normal People. I definitely see the parallels, they both follow the intertwined lives of two people as they navigate romance, friendships, life, school, and career. In contrast with Normal People, I Think Tomorrow, and Tomorrow and Tomorrow did a better job handling themes of abuse, and did not glorify it with long descriptions. But like Normal people, I found the characters in the book completely abhorrent and disgusting at times.

However, despite the characters flaws, the book remains intriguing, and I kept wanting to read more, even if I didn't care much for the personal happiness of the characters at times. As someone reading this in my twenties, it helped me contextualize where I am at in my life and career, and how much more of life I have left to live and enjoy before my time on this planet is up. It also made me want to make a game.

Title: The Rape of Nanking: The Forgotten Holocaust of World War II
Author: Iris Chang

Title: Babel
Author: R.F. Kuang
My Review: Read this book last year and am still thinking and talking about it nearly every week for a full year.

Title: Sigh, Gone: A Misfit's Memoir of Great Books, Punk Rock, and the Fight to Fit In
Author: Phuc  Tran
My Review:
The book is primarily about the author, Phuc Tran's high school experience. While I enjoyed it, it often felt like it was written for high schoolers. I think if I were to read this when I was back in grade school, I would have enjoyed it much more than I did reading it today.

I liked reading about Tran's punk coming-of-age and the antics and identity he used to define himself throughout his adolescence. I enjoyed reading about his love for reading and literature and how it made him feel less alone to read the mistakes, hopes, and fears of authors of the past, a sentiment I resonate with. I thought Tran was a likable protagonist, although I did not always feel he was entirely honest in the picture he painted of himself as a youth. His narration feels too rose-colored - I would have enjoyed a more nuanced picture of him not always doing the right thing and coming up short while he figured himself out.

A reoccurring pattern in this book was that Tran would give a potent anecdote from his life, then add some introspection but stop short of how deep I wished his introspection would go. The times where he does go deeper, for example, addressing the racism and misogyny within his own group of friends, I enjoyed it and wish it happened more often. Perhaps it's on me as the reader to discern these deeper meanings and read between the lines to understand how the different experiences of Trans life and identity affected one another. It would be a natural exercise for me if I were reading fiction, but in a memoir, I don't want to project those assumptions onto the lived experiences of a real person. Part of my disappointment came from Tran himself talking about the intricacies of the literature and philosophy that inspired him, and I expected more from him after reading about how the things he read and wrote in high school. I can only hope Tran will eventually write another book where he delves into his life post-high school with more introspection and depth for a more mature audience.

Title: Decolonising the Mind: The Politics of Language in African Literature
Author: Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o

Title: Hunger: A Memoir of (My) Body
Author: Roxane Gay
My Review:
This is an extraordinary memoir; I was so encapsulated that I read it in a day. Roxane Gay does a phenomenal job of using sparse but powerful language to represent the full range of human emotions throughout this novel. It gave me a completely different feminist perspective that I feel has been missing in much of the literature I've read in the past few years. Her writing about her experiences of weight and beauty within a violent patriarchy is phenomenal. It frames eating disorders and obesity as not just a medical issue but a feminist one at its core.

Would highly recommend.

Title: The Book of Mormon: Another Testament of Jesus Christ
Author: Joseph Smith Jr.
Publisher: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
My Review: boring when interpreted as fiction, unfulfilling when interpreted as nonfiction

Title: The Catcher in the Rye
Author: J.D. Salinger
My Review:
Read this in two days. I never read this in middle/high school like most people had, but it's been on my list to read as an adult for a while.

The book deals a lot with the doubts, fears, and angst of growing up, especially as a teenage boy. I recognized a lot of my teenage self in Holden. Still, as a whole, I found I simply didn't want to read the ramblings of a character so hypocritical, pessimistic, and annoying. Like many other 'American classic' novels, I found most of the value of reading this book in being a part of the conversation around it. People have been dissecting and analyzing every part of this book for decades, and its status as a literary legend means that there's lots of thoughtful discourse to engage in that is more interesting than the book itself.

I thought the book would hit harder since I've also been thinking a lot recently about growing up and feeling directionless (and I live in New York City). Tbh, I think the Diary of a Wimpy Kid series is just as worthwhile to read if you're looking for some hypocritical teenage angst from an insecure narrator - although slightly more sociopathic.

Title: Give Me My Father's Body: The Life of Minik, the New York Eskimo
Author: Kenn Harper

Title: Educated
Author: Tara Westover
My Review:
I could not put down this book once I started it. The author's storytelling is gripping in a way that makes me utterly unsurprised that it was a bestseller for so long. I found this story incredibly inspirational, as the author challenges all of the assumptions she grew up with, shakes off the fears and worries of her upbringing, and goes forth into the world with so much passion and sees enormous success and happiness. I also found myself incredibly frustrated at times with the author, as it takes her years to leave, what is clear to the reader and the author in hindsight, an extreme cycle of abuse with her family. However, I left the book with a sense of optimism and an insane amount of respect and empathy for Tara Westover.

This book has been on my radar for years. Many of my friends know I'm ex-mormon, and a lot of them mentioned this book to me throughout the years. The author starts the book with a disclaimer that this book is not a criticism of Mormonism and is not relatable to the average Mormon experience. Still, I didn't find that entirely true. While it's true that every Mormon approaches the religion differently, I recognized many feelings and sentiments of the author's parents that rang true to what I experienced with my parents and other adults in the church, although usually to a lesser degree. Growing up with people whose entire livelihoods, moral framework, and life views are dictated by the Mormon church and subject to change at any time due to "personal revelation" is a reality to millions of people in the United States. After telling my parents I had left the church after going off to college, I once awoke to my mother standing over me, telling me she had a personal revelation from God that I was mentally poisoning my younger siblings, telling them to leave the church as I had.

Westover also spoke to a feeling I hadn't ever put into words: a deep melancholy at leaving the Mormon community. Of occasionally returning to a place and to people you know you had outgrown. Maybe it just hit especially hard because I read it during the holidays when I was visiting my still Mormon parents, having the same religious and moral discussions we've had a dozen times since I left the church.

This book was also the kick I needed to finally get documents notarized to formalize leaving the Mormon church, so thank you for that, Ms. Westover.

Title: Sky Raiders (Five Kingdoms, #1)
Author: Brandon Mull
My Review: re-read this series recently and wtf it stands the test of time even as a 24-year old. The characters being in middle school throws you off a bit though considering how they're always in grown-ass situations. But that made it relatable for me back when I first read it.

Title: Normal People
Author: Sally Rooney
My Review:
It's worth reading. I picked it up based on a Goodreads review and listened to the audiobook throughout two nights. It touched upon many feelings on my mind over the past few months. It gave me a lot to think about along the themes of:
- The inherent power dynamic that occurs in relationships between men and women.
- The role physical intimacy plays in relationships and how the emotional relationship dynamics are tied to the physical ones.
- What you owe to other people. From what you owe to a sexual partner to what you owe to a romantic partner to what you owe to friends, families, and strangers.

I found the descriptions of Connell's loneliness and depression, the feelings that he isn't good enough, and his shame in his past mistakes incredibly moving and relatable. It made me feel like I wasn't alone. This character exploration was the high point to me in the book and has affected how I contextualize my thoughts around these themes in my personal life. I do wish this had been more of a focus, however. I feel like the novel doesn't address his depression treatment much beyond explaining that he started medication.

I also think that the way this book fetishizes abuse and revels in the possibility of Connell abusing Marianne is gross and overdone. Connell consistently treats Marianne like shit throughout the book, and I feel like the book is encouraging us to see him as changed after high school, when in reality, he's only acting slightly less bad than he was in high school. This made me less interested in reading the book, but I always have a hard time caring about the main characters that I think are bad people. However, the book did make Connell a complex enough character for me to stay attentive.
